subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] keyboard/lexical set proposal
msgSnippet: ... I felt *all* these to be quite natural parts of fast writing, and so took to learn them immediately, but to me the half-letters were the easiest part,
messageBody:
On 2007-12-18 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> In my view, the alternate letters for #23 and #36 make
> reading easier. When I first read the QM, the half-letters
> and advanced letter connections seemed difficult, but the
> alternate letters were as easy to learn as any other
> letters in the QS alphabet. They are, after all, just
> letters, and it didn't occur to me that I should postpone
> learning them just because they are introduced in the
> Senior section of the manual.

I felt *all* these to be quite natural parts of fast
writing, and so took to learn them immediately, but to me
the half-letters were the easiest part, while the alternate
letters were the most reluctant -- especially alternate #23.
OTOH once I'd learned to use alternate #23 I took to want an
alternate #21 as well, not no mention half #7 and half #17
-- although the need for those may depend on how often you
write "through", "think" and "yet"! The strangest part of if
is that I regularly use a shorthand system which normally
uses alternate forms of some consonant shapes depending on
the preceding vowel shapes. I guess it all goes to show that
your mileage may vary.


/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
if grammarians discuss them.
-Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
